Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The bill, introduced for years by Omaha state Sen. Justin Wayne, passed by a wide margin in the last year of Wayne’s second term.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced the bill for years; in the last year of Wayne’s second term

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The passage of the bill “means everything for the thousands of people who have not been full participants in society,” said TJ King, a Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink who was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: King said the bill’s passage is the final layer in his ability to be civically engaged and “have a full voice and complete connection to the community.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Nebraska-based outreach specialist with the advocacy group Black and Pink
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was unable to vote in the 2022 general election after coming off probation for drug and theft convictions three months earlier

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Studies have shown that if you allow people to engage in their community upon being released, the recidivism rate drops,” Wayne said during a public hearing for the bill last year.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced the bill for years; in the last year of Wayne’s second term

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We spend on average $42,000 a year on prisoners, of which we have around a 30 percent recidivism rate.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced the bill for years; in the last year of Wayne’s second term

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “One year, I brought in a little chart that says if we just cut it by 10 percent, we’re saving around $5 million a year.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: introduced the bill for years; in the last year of Wayne’s second term

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: As a result, voting rights have been restored to over 2 million people, said Nicole Porter, senior director of advocacy at The Sentencing Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior director of advocacy at The Sentencing Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: The Sentencing Project studies criminal justice policy

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: As of October 2023, 26 states and the District of Columbia had expanded voting rights to people living with felony convictions, according to The Sentencing Project, a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a nonprofit sentencing advocacy group that studies criminal justice policy
